skills.name: Write 5 digit numbers and above as words
Express words between 10 and 20 as numbers
Express words as 5 digit numbers and above

explanations.A: 90 is "ninety". Nineteen has a teen at the end. It might help to think about how old TEENagers usually are.
explanations.B: 9 is "nine". Nineteen has a teen at the end. It might help to think about how old TEENagers usually are.
explanations.C: 91 is "ninety one". Nineteen has a teen at the end. It might help to think about how old TEENagers usually are.

explanations.A: 71 is "seventy one". Seventeen has a teen at the end. It might help to think about how old TEENagers usually are.
explanations.C: 70 is "seventy". Seventeen has a teen at the end. It might help to think about how old TEENagers usually are.
explanations.D: 7 is "seven". Seventeen has a teen at the end. It might help to think about how old TEENagers usually are.

explanations.A: Although these numbers could be written separately as ten and seven, you need to take care of the place value. What does the 1 represent here?
explanations.B: This number can be thought of in the following way: 107 = 100 + 7. It then follows that we have one hundred and seven.
explanations.C: One hundred and seventy is 100 + 70 = 170. You appear to have switched the 7 and 0 around. The 7 is in the units column here, what does it represent?
explanations.D: Seventeen is 17, there's a 0 in between the 1 and 7 here. What place value column is the 1 in here?

explanations.A: Although these numbers could be written separately as twenty and nine, you need to take care of the place value. What does the 2 represent here?
explanations.B: Two hundred and ninety is 200 + 90 = 290. You appear to have switched the 9 and 0 around. The 9 is in the units column here, what does it represent?
explanations.C: This number can be thought of in the following way: 209 = 200 + 9. It then follows that we have two hundred and nine.
explanations.D: Although these digits could be written separately as two, zero and nine, when they are together, you can say them as one number. To help you, think about what place value the 2 represents

explanations.A: Starting at the left-hand side and working to the right: there are 3 lots of 10 = 3 × 10 = 30; 4 lots of 1 = 4 × 1 = 4; and 2 lots of 100 = 2 × 100 = 200. In total, this gives us an answer of 30 + 4 + 200 = 234
explanations.B: I think you've been thrown off by the order of the images. The 2 hundred squares represent more than the 3 ten strips. Think about the place value of the digits you've used.
explanations.C: I think you've been thrown off by the order of the images. The 2 hundred squares represent more than the 3 ten strips. Think about the place value of the digits you've used.
explanations.D: I think you've been thrown off by the order of the images. The 4 units represent less than the 3 ten strips. Think about the place value of the digits you've used.

explanations.A: I think you've been thrown off by the order of the images. The hundred square represents more than the 4 ten strips. Think about the place value of the digits you've used.
explanations.B: I think you've been thrown off by the order of the images. The hundred square represents more than the 4 ten strips. Think about the place value of the digits you've used.
explanations.C: Starting at the left-hand side and working to the right: there are 4 lots of 10 = 4 × 10 = 40; 3 lots of 1 = 3 × 1 = 3; and 1 lot of 100 = 1 × 100 = 100. In total, this gives us an answer of 40 + 3 + 100 = 143
explanations.D: I think you've been thrown off by the order of the images. The 3 units represent less than the 4 ten strips. Think about the place value of the digits you've used.

explanations.A: This would be 2,004,050. Think about your place value for all of your digits. Working from the right (with no decimal point), we have units, tens, hundreds, thousands, ten thousands, hundred thousands, millions.
explanations.B: Using our place value, and working from the right (where there is no decimal point), we have 0 units, 5 tens (fifty), 0 hundreds, 4 thousands, 0 ten thousands, 2 hundred thousands. We can group the thousands together for two hundred and four thousand, and the rest group as fifty. So we have "two hundred and four thousand and fifty".
explanations.C: This would mean 204+50=254, think about your place value for all of your digits. The 204 at the front represents a higher place value than the next three digits. It might help you to think about what the 4 represents.
explanations.D: Look carefully at your place value. This would be 240,050.

explanations.A: This would be 3,007,050. Think about your place value for all of your digits. Working from the right (with no decimal point), we have units, tens, hundreds, thousands, ten thousands, hundred thousands, millions.
explanations.B: Look carefully at your place value. This would be 370,060. What does the 7 actually represent here?
explanations.C: This would mean 307+60=367, think about your place value for all of your digits. The 307 at the front represents a higher place value than the next three digits. It might help you to think about what the 7 represents.
explanations.D: Using our place value, and working from the right (where there is no decimal point), we have 0 units, 6 tens (sixty), 0 hundreds, 7 thousands, 0 ten thousands, 3 hundred thousands. We can group the thousands together for three hundred and seven thousand, and the rest group as sixty. So we have "three hundred and seven thousand and sixty".

explanations.A: You appear to have forgotten what one million is worth; this number would be "Two billion, three hundred thousand and four". Remember that one million is 1 000 000
explanations.B: Try reading the number again, I think you've missed the "thousand".
explanations.C: It can be easier to think of the parts separately, remembering that one million has six zeros. Therefore, two million, three hundred thousand and four = 2 000 000 + 300 000 + 4. Putting this together, gives 2 300 004.
explanations.D: You appear to have forgotten what one million and one hundred thousand are worth; this number would be "Two hundred and thirty thousand and four". Remember that one million is 1 000 000

explanations.A: Try reading the number again, I think you've missed the "thousand".
explanations.B: You appear to have forgotten what one million is worth; this number would be "Eight billion, two hundred thousand and six". Remember that one million is 1 000 000
explanations.C: You appear to have forgotten what one million and one hundred thousand are worth; this number would be "Eight hundred and twenty thousand and six". Remember that one million is 1 000 000
explanations.D: It can be easier to think of the parts separately, remembering that one million has six zeros. Therefore, eight million, two hundred thousand and six = 8 000 000 + 200 000 + 6. Putting this together, gives 8 200 006.
